SEARCH
Package org.jboss.elemento.intl

Interface DateTimeFormatOptions

@JsType(isNative=true, namespace="<global>") public interface DateTimeFormatOptions
Mapping for date time format options passed to DateTimeFormat constructors.

In addition to the actual mappings, this class implements the builder pattern using enums to create the options easily and in a type-safe manner. Some enums are shared with other format option builders of the Intl module and may contain more values than intended for the given method. In that case the allowed values are listed on the method. In all other cases all enum values are applicable. 

var date = new JsDate(2012, 11, 17, 4, 0, 42);

console.log(new DateTimeFormat("en-GB", DateTimeFormatOptions.create()
        .hour(numeric)
        .hourCycle(h12)
        .dayPeriod(short_)
        .timeZone("UTC")).format(date));
// 4 at night" (same formatting in en-GB for all dayPeriod values)

console.log(new DateTimeFormat("fr", DateTimeFormatOptions.create()
        .hour(numeric)
        .hourCycle(h12)
        .dayPeriod(narrow)
        .timeZone("UTC")).format(date));
// "4 mat." (same output in French for both narrow/short dayPeriod)

console.log(new DateTimeFormat("fr", DateTimeFormatOptions.create()
        .hour(numeric)
        .hourCycle(h12)
        .dayPeriod(long_)
        .timeZone("UTC")).format(date));
// "4 du matin"
See Also:
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl/DateTimeFormat/DateTimeFormat#options

    • calendar

      @JsOverlay default DateTimeFormatOptions calendar(String calendar)
      The calendar to use, such as "chinese", "gregory", "persian", and so on. For a list of supported calendar types, see Intl.supportedValuesOf(Category).

    • timeZone

      @JsOverlay default DateTimeFormatOptions timeZone(String timeZone)
      The time zone to use. Can be any IANA time zone name, including named identifiers such as "UTC", "America/New_York", and "Etc/GMT+8", and offset identifiers such as "+01:00", "-2359", and "+23". The default is the runtime's time zone.
